subject: Law
title: The Federalist Papers
description: A 1-minute de-risking session on The Federalist Papers.

hook.text: Three men wrote 85 newspaper essays to convince America to adopt the Constitution. It worked.

buildup.text: The Federalist Papers, by Hamilton, Madison, and Jay, argued for ratifying the Constitution and explained its design.

discovery.text: Federalist No. 10 addressed factions. No. 51 explained checks and balances. No. 78 defended judicial independence.

twist.text: They were written under the pseudonym 'Publius.' Authorship wasn't confirmed for decades.

climax.text: The Supreme Court cites them regularly to interpret the Founders' intent. They remain a primary legal source.

punchline.text: Newspaper essays became constitutional canon. Words can build nations.

quiz.question: What was the purpose of the Federalist Papers?
options: To argue for ratifying the Constitution
To amend the Articles of Confederation
